channel.title: National Association of Educational Broadcasters 39th Annual Convention, 1963
channel.description:
These recordings featured highlights from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters 39th Annual Convention in 1963.,These recordings featured highlights from the 1963 National Association of Educational Broadcasters 39th Annual Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

image.title: National Association of Educational Broadcasters 39th Annual Convention, 1963

item.title: E. William Henry - Reel 1 of 2
item.description: This session features remarks by E. William Henry, commissioner of the Federal Communications Commission, focusing on educational television.
item.dc:creator: National Association of Educational Broadcasters
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government--20th century

item.title: National Association of Educational Broadcasters Convention Lawrence T. Frymire
item.description: This session included remarks by Dr. Lawrence T. Frymire Ph.D., founding executive director of the New Jersey Network.
item.dc:creator: National Association of Educational Broadcasters
item.dc:subject: United States

item.title: Robert L. Shayon - Reel 1 of 2
item.description: This session features remarks by Robert L. Shayon, the distinguished contributing editor of The Saturday Review, and writer, producer, and director of some of the most stimulating radio programs ever created--You Are There, The Eagle's Brood, Everybody's Mountain--as well as the educational television series The Whole Town's Talking.
item.dc:creator: National Association of Educational Broadcasters
item.dc:subject: United States

item.title: Robert L. Shayon - Reel 2 of 2
item.description: This session features remarks by Robert L. Shayon, the distinguished contributing editor of The Saturday Review, and writer, producer, and director of some of the most stimulating radio programs ever created--You Are There, The Eagle's Brood, Everybody's Mountain--as well as the educational television series The Whole Town's Talking.
item.dc:creator: National Association of Educational Broadcasters
item.dc:subject: United States

item.title: NABE Convention "Broadcasting of Public Affairs" Hugh M. Robinson
item.description: Captain Hugh M. Robinson, who worked in the Pentagonâ€™s public information office during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962, discussed the dual importance of protecting sensitive information while informing the American public.
item.dc:creator: National Association of Educational Broadcasters
item.dc:subject: United States

item.title: Broadcaster vs. Educator: A Conflict
item.description: The speaker, a Canadian broadcaster, makes the argument that the tradition of broadcasting relates to the use of radio to communicate to people whereas the traditions of education relate to instructing people, formally or otherwise. The traditions of educational broadcasting therefore should relate to instructing people while they are being communicated to. He humbly submits that educational broadcasters are often so absorbed with their nobility of purpose that they are unwisely taking the communication process for granted, creating a conflict of purpose.
item.dc:creator: National Association of Educational Broadcasters
item.dc:subject: United States
